{"uri": "2024-06-377341753", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "14:54:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T14:54:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T14:53:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://eu.courier-journal.com/story/news/politics/2024/06/03/hunter-biden-trial-live-updates/73949001007/", "title": "Hunter Biden trial live updates: Joe Biden's son faces felony gun charges in Delaware", "body": "For the first time in U.S. history, the child of a sitting president will be on trial as Hunter Biden faces felony gun charges.\n\nWILMINGTON, Del. - The Biden family, including first lady Jill Biden, has come out in force for Hunter Biden's felony gun trial. In addition to Jill Biden, Hunter's wife, Melissa Cohen Biden, and a sister, Ashley Biden, are attending the first day of his trial on federal gun charges Monday.\n\nPresident Joe Biden is not attending, but he changed his schedule to be in Wilmington for the first day of his son's trial. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today,\" the president said in a statement. \"Hunter's resilience in the face of adversity and the strength he has brought to his recovery are inspiring to us.\"\n\nThe trial comes four days after former President Donald Trump was found guilty of falsifying business records in New York, and after the stunning collapse of a plea deal with federal investigators last year.\n\nBiden is facing three firearm felonies, all of which focus on whether he lied on a federal gun form in 2018 that asked if he was addicted to drugs.\n\nTrial is expected to explore the depths of Biden's drug use and follow a bizarre series of events in which he purchased a gun that authorities recovered after it was thrown into a trash can in a Delaware grocery store weeks later.\n\nFollow along with the USA TODAY Network's live coverage as jury selection begins.\n\nHow long is the trial expected to last?\n\nHunter Biden's trial on federal gun charges in the family's hometown of Wilmington, Delaware, could last more than two weeks.\n\nFederal prosecutors have said in court filings they will present photos, testimony and messages to show that Hunter Biden was an illegal drug user around the time he bought the gun and failed to disclose that as required on a federal gun purchase form.\n\nProsecutors also said they may use details gleaned from his phone, iCloud account and the infamous laptop that he allegedly abandoned at a repair store, including photos of Hunter Biden smoking crack and texts arranging meetings with illegal drug dealers.\n\n- Reuters\n\nMore: Hunter Biden bursts into public view: Here's how the president's son will play a central role in 2024\n\nWhat is Hunter Biden being charged with?\n\nThe president's son faces three firearms felonies.\n\nIn October 2018, Hunter Biden walked into a gun shop north of Wilmington, Delaware, and purchased a revolver. People who purchase firearms are required to fill out a standardized form that asks whether they are an unlawful user or are addicted to controlled substances, narcotics and other listed substances. Biden is accused of answering \"no\" to that question on the form.\n\nBut Biden has been open about his longtime struggles with crack cocaine addiction. He's written about it in his 2021 memoir, \"Beautiful Things,\" and discussed it during a court hearing last year, stating he's been sober since 2019.\n\nBiden faces a maximum sentence of 25 years in prison if convicted, although first-time and non-violent offenders are often given shorter terms.\n\n- Xerxes Wilson\n\nMore: What is an addict? Hunter Biden is fighting what that means as gun trial looms\n\nSee the questions lawyers will ask potential Hunter Biden jurors\n\nHere are the 47 questions potenial jurors will be asked as Judge Maryellen Noreika looks for twelve impartial Delaware residents to take their seats at Hunter Biden's federal gun trial. The questionnaire gets to the heart of the unusual case involving the president's son, drug addiction and firearms. Among the questions:\n\nU.S. District Judge Maryellen Noreika began questioning potential jurors in Hunter Biden's trial on gun charges and explained rules for participating in the case, including not reading media coverage.\n\nShe aims to seat 12 jurors and four alternates.\n\nNoreika is asking potential jurors whether they can impartially review the evidence in the case. Questions include whether potential jurors know anyone involved in the case, along with general inquiries about their thoughts on politics, law enforcement and issues surrounding addiction.\n\nJurors who answer \"yes\" to one of the screening questions will be further questioned by the judge. Those interviews are occurring now. Out of the first pool of what was scheduled to be 50 potential jurors, only one did not answer \"yes\" to one of the screening questions, meaning this process will likely take a long time.\n\n-Xerxes Wilson\n\nPresident Joe Biden supports Hunter as trial begins\n\nPresident Joe Biden issued a statement Monday supporting his son as Hunter Biden's federal gun trial begins.\n\n\"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today,\" Joe Biden said. \"Hunter's resilience in the face of adversity and the strength he has brought to his recovery are inspiring to us.\"\n\nJoe Biden said he wouldn't comment as president on pending federal cases. But he said he has confidence in his son and respect for him.\n\n\"Our family has been through a lot together, and Jill and I are going to continue to be there for Hunter and our family with our love and support,\" Joe Biden said.\n\n--Bart Jansen\n\nHunter Biden also faces civil trial against his ex-wife over alimony\n\nHunter Biden isn't just facing sweeping legal problems over gun and tax charges. Axios reported last week that - in 2021 - a Washington court found he was in breach of an agreement with his ex-wife Kathleen Buhle. At the time, he owed her over $1.7 million in legal fees, spousal support and other costs from their 2017 divorce.\n\nSince then, Buhle and Biden's legal battle has continued, and her attorneys have argued he still owes her millions.\n\n- Marina Pitofsky\n\nHunter Biden's family stays close for federal trial\n\nHunter Biden's relatives stayed close for his trial on federal gun charges, with his father, President Biden, remaining in Wilmington on Sunday night for the start of jury selection Monday.\n\nHunter Biden arrived at court holding hands with his wife, Melissa Cohen Biden. His mother Jill and sister Ashley arrived separately. Hunter Biden's past drug use is at the heart of charges he lied on a federal form and to a gun dealer when buying a guy in 2018.\n\nThe two courtroom benches behind Hunter Biden and his defense team, where Jill and Ashley Biden were seated, were filled before the jury was called into the courtroom.\n\nMore: As Trump's trial nears an end, the Bidens prep for a month in legal purgatory\n\nThe family support contrasted slightly with the attendance at another high-profile trial, that of former President Donald Trump in New York. He was convicted Thursday of falsifying business records to cover up his role in a hush money payment to porn actress Stormy Daniels before the 2016 election.\n\nTrump's wife Melania, daughter Ivanka and son Barron Trump didn't attend the six-week trial. His sons Donald Junior and Eric attended occasionally, and daughter Tiffany Trump appeared for closing arguments.\n\n-Bart Jansen and Esteban Parra\n\nHunter Biden trial hunts for jurors without connections to famous family\n\nAs jury selection begins in Hunter Biden's trial on federal gun charges, one challenge will be finding jurors who don't have a connection to the first family in the First State.\n\n\"Good luck getting that jury,\" said Dori Jacobson, a Greenville resident who lives not far from President Biden's residence.\n\nHunter Biden's father, President Joe Biden, has been a ubiquitous presence since serving decades as a senator and then as vice president. Potential jurors won't be asked about interactions at Pep Boys, worshipping at St. Joseph on the Brandywine or watching his grandchildren's flag football games, but they will be asked about connections to the family.\n\n\"Are you, any member of your immediate family, or close friends acquaintances with Robert Hunter Biden or any member of his family?\" reads the seventh of 47 questions listed on the jury selection document.\n\n-Ryan Cormier\n\nMore: When everyone's met a Biden in Delaware, how hard will it be to find a jury?\n\nHunter Biden arrives at federal courthouse for trial on gun charges\n\nHunter Biden arrived about 8:10 a.m. Monday for the start of his trial on federal gun charges.\n\nMore: 'Karma' or 'political prosecution?' Voters weigh in on Hunter Biden criminal trials\n\nTrial's key moment: Was Hunter Biden sober on Oct. 12, 2018?\n\nA large part of Hunter Biden's trial will boil down to a single day in October 2018, when he bought a .38 Special revolver at a Delaware gun store and checked \"No\" on a federal gun form that asked about drug addiction or drug use.\n\nThe federal drug form asked: \"Are you an unlawful user of, or addicted to, marijuana or any depressant, stimulant, narcotic drug, or any other controlled substance?\"\n\n\"At issue here is Mr. Biden's understanding of the question,\" his lawyer Abbe Lowell recently wrote the court. \"Someone like Mr. Biden, who had just completed an 11-day rehabilitation program and lived with a sober companion after that, could surely believe he was not a present tense user or addict.\"\n\nSome drug treatment experts told USA TODAY they wouldn't consider a patient cured of addiction after 11 days of treatment. But they said a person who had just completed treatment might consider themselves sober.\n\nMore: Hunter Biden trial: Why his gun case hinges on one fateful day when he wasn't using drugs\n\nReporters arrive early for Hunter Biden trial\n\nBy 6:45 am, a dozen reporters had lined up outside the J. Caleb Boggs Federal Building in downtown Wilmington for the start of Hunter Biden's will go on trial this week on federal gun charges.\n\nJury selection starts today, with court convening at 8:30 a.m. local time.\n\nThree tents for broadcast stations were set up near the court. A heavy police presence is visible, with several police cars parked along North King Street, which runs along one side the building.\n\nA Department of Homeland Security dog walked up and down the line of reporters, sniffing their bags.\n\nBoggs, the building's late namesake, was a former Republican governor who lost his Senate seat in a 1972 squeaker to Joe Biden.\n\nHunter Biden won't be able to introduce a second federal form during his trial on charges he illegally bought and possessed a gun while addicted to drugs, U.S. District Judge Maryellen Noreika ruled Sunday.\n\nThe president's son is charged with lying on the form and lying to the gun dealer about his drug usage when he bought a .38-caliber pistol in 2018 and had it for 11 days.\n\nOn the initial form submitted to federal authorities soon after buying the gun, Biden put an X next to a question asking if he used narcotics or was addicted to them. The second version of the form was submitted to investigators in 2021 with additional information attached that said Biden submitted his vehicle registration when he bought the gun, which apparently wasn't the case, according to court statements.\n\nBiden's lawyer, Abbe Lowell, sought to question the gun shop owner about the second form, arguing he apparently filled out the form inaccurately, which is the charge against Biden. But prosecutors argued the second form is \"irrelevant\" and would confuse jurors. Noreika agreed and barred the form from trial, in one of two rulings Sunday against the defense.\n\n-Xerxes Wilson\n\nMore: These are the people, places that will take center stage in Hunter Biden's trial\n\nJudge bars defense expert on drug addiction from trial\n\nU.S. District Judge Maryellen Noreika barred testimony from one of Hunter Biden's proposed expert witnesses, who the defense sought to give a perspective about how people suffering drug addiction view themselves.\n\nDefense lawyers sought to have Elie Aoun, an assistant professor of clinical psychiatry, to testify to testify about how people who have participated in rehabilitation programs are sometimes in denial about their addiction and view themselves as no longer addicted when they complete a program.\n\nBut Noreika barred the witness Sunday, in one of two decisions against the dense, by ruling the defense failed to provide prosecutors with a proper explanation about what expert opinions Aoun would offer.\n\nBiden's defense also sought testimony from Michael Coyer, a forensic toxicologist, to answer questions about items including a white residue on a brown leather gun pouch that tested positive for cocaine years after it was taken into police custody. Noreika ruled that she would hear from Coyer without the jury present before deciding whether to allow him to testify.\n\nThe first two relate specifically to the form he filled out to purchase a gun in 2018, accusing Biden of lying about this drug use on the form.\n\nThe third charge pertains to Biden's possession of a firearm while he was allegedly an unlawful user or addicted to controlled substances.\n\nThe charges carry a maximum penalty of 25 years in prison, though Biden is likely to get a shorter sentence if convicted. It is atypical for defendants to get a maximum sentence when they are first-time offenders like Biden.", "source": {"uri": "courier-journal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Courier-Journal"}, {"uri": "8159383476", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "13:05:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T13:05:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T13:05:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/hunter-biden-and-first-lady-jill-biden-arrive-for-jury-selection-in-his-federal-gun/article_84e30c69-6036-5f8b-8f42-4d9af384d101.html", "title": "Hunter Biden and first lady Jill Biden arrive for jury selection in his federal gun case", "body": "Hunter Biden, center, and his wife, Melissa Cohen Biden, right, arrives at federal court, Monday, June 3, 2024, in Wilmington, Del.\n\nWILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- President Joe Biden's son Hunter arrived at court on Monday for jury selection in a federal gun case against him after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. First lady Jill Biden arrived shortly after, entering the courthouse in support of her son.\n\nHunter Biden, who spent the weekend with his parents, has been charged in Delaware with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application used to screen firearms applicants when he said he was not a drug user, and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department, after Republicans decried the now-defunct deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial comes just days after Donald Trump, Republicans' presumptive 2024 presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. A jury found the former president guilty of a scheme to cover up a hush money payment to a porn actor to fend off damage to his 2016 presidential campaign. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the criminal courtroom has taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nHunter Biden is also facing a separate trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through a deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed. The lawyers squabbled over the agreement, could not come to a resolution, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nThis trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs -- which Republicans have seized on without evidence to try to paint the Biden family as corrupt. But it will excavate some of Hunter Biden's darkest moments and put them on display.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about the well-being and sobriety of his only living son and who must now watch as those painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. He's also protective: Hunter Biden was with his father all weekend before the case began, biking with his dad and attending church together.\n\nPresident Biden, in a last-minute switch in plans, shifted from his Rehoboth Beach home back to his Wilmington compound on Sunday evening. Boarding a helicopter on Sunday was the only time the president was seen publicly without his son all weekend.\n\nHunter Biden arrived first at the Delaware courthouse on Monday. The first lady, who turned 73 on Monday, followed about 15 minutes later and walked briskly into court, flanked by U.S. Secret Service agents.\n\nAllies are also worried the trial could become a distraction as the president tries to campaign under anemic poll numbers and as he is preparing for an upcoming presidential debate while the proceedings play out.\n\nProsecutors are hoping to show Hunter Biden was in the throes of addiction when he bought the gun and therefore lied on the forms. They have said they're planning to use as evidence his published memoir, and they may also introduce contents from a laptop that he left at a Delaware repair shop and never retrieved. The contents made their way to Republicans in 2020 and were publicly leaked, revealing embarrassing and personal photos in which he's often nude and doing drugs and messages in which he asks dealers about scores.\n\nThe judge will ask a group of prospective jurors a series of questions to determine whether they can serve impartially on the jury, including whether they have donated to political campaigns or run for political office. She will ask whether their views about the 2024 presidential campaign prevent them from being impartial.\n\nShe's also going to ask whether prospective jurors believe Hunter Biden is being prosecuted because his father is the president. Also, she'll ask about firearms purchasing and addiction issues, including: \"Do you believe someone who is addicted to drugs should not be charged with a crime?\"\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent into drugs and alcohol followed the 2015 death of his brother, Beau Biden, from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nHunter Biden has pleaded not guilty in both cases, and his attorneys have suggested they may argue he didn't see himself as an addict when prosecutors say he checked \"no\" to the question on the form. They'll also attack the credibility of the gun store owner.\n\nProsecutors, meanwhile, are also planning to call as witnesses Hunter Biden's ex-wife and his brother's widow, Hallie, with whom he became romantically involved.\n\nIf he were to be convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press Writer Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington contributed to this report. Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden arrives ahead of Hunter Biden\u00b4s trial at a federal court in Wilmington, Delaware (AP)\n\nHunter Biden, who spent the weekend with his parents, has been charged in the US state of Delaware with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction.\n\nHe has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application used to screen firearms applicants when he said he was not a drug user, and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nBiden has pleaded not guilty and has argued he is being unfairly targeted by the US justice department, after Republicans decried the now-defunct deal as special treatment for the Democratic President's son.\n\nThe trial comes just days after Donald Trump, Republicans' presumptive 2024 presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City.\n\nA jury found the former president guilty of a scheme to cover up a hush money payment to a porn actor to fend off damage to his 2016 presidential campaign. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underlines how the criminal courtroom has taken centre stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nHunter Biden is also facing a separate trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay 1.4 million dollars in taxes.\n\nHunter Biden arrives at federal court, with his wife Melissa Cohen Biden (AP)\n\nBoth cases were to have been resolved through a deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a years-long investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Mr Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanour offences to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers squabbled over the agreement, could not come to a resolution, and the deal fell apart.\n\nUS attorney general Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nThis trial is not about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs - which Republicans have seized on without evidence to try to paint the Biden family as corrupt. But it will excavate some of Hunter Biden's darkest moments and put them on display.\n\nMr Biden said he is proud of the man his son is today (AP)\n\nThe President's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who has long been concerned about the wellbeing and sobriety of his only living son and who must now watch as those painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinised.\n\nHe is also protective: Hunter Biden was with his father all weekend before the case began, biking with his father and attending church together.\n\nPresident Biden, in a last-minute switch in plans, shifted from his Rehoboth Beach home back to his Wilmington compound on Sunday evening. Boarding a helicopter on Sunday was the only time the US President was seen publicly without his son all weekend.\n\nHunter Biden arrived first at the Delaware courthouse on Monday. The first lady, who turned 73 on Monday, followed about 15 minutes later and walked briskly into court, flanked by US secret service agents. Hunter Biden's sister Ashley Biden was also in court to support him.\n\nThe US President was out biking with his son over the weekend (AP)\n\nAllies are also worried the trial could become a distraction as the president tries to campaign under anaemic poll numbers and as he is preparing for an upcoming presidential debate while the proceedings play out.\n\nProsecutors are hoping to show Hunter Biden was in the throes of addiction when he bought the gun and therefore lied on the forms. They have said they are planning to use as evidence his published memoir, and they may also introduce contents from a laptop that he left at a Delaware repair shop and never retrieved.\n\nThe contents made their way to Republicans in 2020 and were publicly leaked, revealing embarrassing and personal photos in which Hunter Biden often nude and doing drugs, and messages in which he asks dealers about scores.\n\nThe judge will ask a group of prospective jurors a series of questions to determine whether they can serve impartially on the jury, including whether they have donated to political campaigns or run for political office.\n\nShe will ask whether their views about the 2024 presidential campaign prevent them from being impartial.\n\nThe judge is also going to ask whether prospective jurors believe Hunter Biden is being prosecuted because his father is the President. {"uri": "8159573487", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "15:08:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T15:08:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T15:07:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/news/politics/2024/06/03/as-jury-selection-starts-in-hunter-bidens-gun-case-president-says-he-has-boundless-love-for-him/", "title": "As jury selection starts in Hunter Biden's gun case, president says he has 'boundless love' for him", "body": "WILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- A federal gun case against President Joe Biden's son Hunter opened Monday with jury selection, following the collapse of a plea deal that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close the 2024 election.\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden was seated in the front row of the courtroom, in a show of support for her son.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn a statement, the president said that as a dad he has \"boundless love for my son, confidence in him, and respect for his strength.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he said, adding that would have no further comment on the case. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nPolitical Points\n\nGet the latest politics news from North Texas and beyond.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nHunter Biden, who spent the weekend with his parents, has been charged in Delaware with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application used to screen firearms applicants when he said he was not a drug user, and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department, after Republicans decried the now-defunct deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe trial comes just days after Donald Trump, Republicans' presumptive 2024 presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. A jury found the former president guilty of a scheme to cover up a hush money payment to a porn actor to fend off damage to his 2016 presidential campaign. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the criminal courtroom has taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nThe judge will ask a group of prospective jurors a series of questions to determine whether they can serve impartially on the jury, including whether they have donated to political campaigns or run for political office. She will ask whether their views about the 2024 presidential campaign prevent them from being impartial.\n\nShe's also going to ask whether prospective jurors believe Hunter Biden is being prosecuted because his father is the president. Also, she will ask about firearms purchasing and addiction issues, including: \"Do you believe someone who is addicted to drugs should not be charged with a crime?\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHunter Biden is also facing a separate trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through a deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed. The lawyers squabbled over the agreement, could not come to a resolution, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nThis trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs -- which Republicans have seized on without evidence to try to paint the Biden family as corrupt. But it will excavate some of Hunter Biden's darkest moments and put them on display.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about the well-being and sobriety of his only living son and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. He's also protective: Hunter Biden was with his father all weekend before the case began, biking with his dad and attending church together.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nPresident Biden, in a last-minute switch in plans, shifted from his Rehoboth Beach home back to his Wilmington compound on Sunday evening. Boarding a helicopter on Sunday was the only time the president was seen publicly without his son all weekend.\n\nHunter Biden arrived first to the Delaware courthouse on Monday. The first lady, who turned 73 on Monday, followed about 15 minutes later and walked briskly into court, flanked by U.S. Secret Service agents. Hunter Biden's sister Ashley Biden was also in court to support him. The president was at their Wilmington home until he left later in the day for a campaign reception in Greenwich, Connecticut.\n\nAllies are also worried the trial could become a distraction as the president tries to campaign under anemic poll numbers and as he is preparing for an upcoming presidential debate while the proceedings play out.\n\nProsecutors hope to show Hunter Biden was in the throes of addiction when he bought the gun and therefore lied on the forms. They have said they're planning to use as evidence his published memoir, and they may also introduce contents from a laptop that he left at a Delaware repair shop and never retrieved. The contents made their way to Republicans in 2020 and were publicly leaked, revealing embarrassing and personal photos in which he's often nude and doing drugs and messages in which he asks dealers about scores.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent into drugs and alcohol followed the 2015 death of his brother, Beau Biden, from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nHunter Biden has pleaded not guilty in both cases, and his attorneys have suggested they may argue he didn't see himself as an addict when prosecutors say he checked \"no\" to the question on the form. They'll also attack the credibility of the gun store owner.\n\nProsecutors, meanwhile, are also planning to call as witnesses Hunter Biden's ex-wife and his brother's widow, Hallie, with whom he became romantically involved.\n\nIf he were to be convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.", "source": {"uri": "dallasnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Dallas Morning News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9615607", "eventUri": "eng-9615607", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Wilmington, Delaware"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": {"uri": "8159450221", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "13:47:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T13:47:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T13:47:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.dailypress.com/2024/06/03/as-hunter-bidens-gun-case-starts-jury-selection-president-says-he-has-boundless-love-for-him/", "title": "As Hunter Biden's gun case starts jury selection, president says he has 'boundless love' for him", "body": "By Randall Chase | Associated Press, Claudia Lauer | Associated Press, Michael Kunzelman | Associated Press and Colleen Long | The Associated Press\n\nBy RANDALL CHASE, CLAUDIA LAUER, MICHAEL KUNZELMAN and COLLEEN LONG (Associated Press)\n\nWILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- President Joe Biden's son Hunter arrived at court on Monday for jury selection in a federal gun case against him after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. First lady Jill Biden arrived shortly after, entering the courthouse in support of her son.\n\nJoe Biden said that as president he wouldn't comment on the criminal trial but as a dad he has \"boundless love for my son, confidence in him, and respect for his strength.\"\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he said in a statement. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nHunter Biden, who spent the weekend with his parents, has been charged in Delaware with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application used to screen firearms applicants when he said he was not a drug user, and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department, after Republicans decried the now-defunct deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial comes just days after Donald Trump, Republicans' presumptive 2024 presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. A jury found the former president guilty of a scheme to cover up a hush money payment to a porn actor to fend off damage to his 2016 presidential campaign. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the criminal courtroom has taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nHunter Biden is also facing a separate trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through a deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed. The lawyers squabbled over the agreement, could not come to a resolution, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nThis trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs -- which Republicans have seized on without evidence to try to paint the Biden family as corrupt. But it will excavate some of Hunter Biden's darkest moments and put them on display.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about the well-being and sobriety of his only living son and who must now watch as those painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. He's also protective: Hunter Biden was with his father all weekend before the case began, biking with his dad and attending church together.\n\nPresident Biden, in a last-minute switch in plans, shifted from his Rehoboth Beach home back to his Wilmington compound on Sunday evening. Boarding a helicopter on Sunday was the only time the president was seen publicly without his son all weekend.\n\nHunter Biden arrived first at the Delaware courthouse on Monday. The first lady, who turned 73 on Monday, followed about 15 minutes later and walked briskly into court, flanked by U.S. Secret Service agents. Hunter Biden's sister Ashley Biden was also in court to support him.\n\nAllies are also worried the trial could become a distraction as the president tries to campaign under anemic poll numbers and as he is preparing for an upcoming presidential debate while the proceedings play out.\n\nProsecutors are hoping to show Hunter Biden was in the throes of addiction when he bought the gun and therefore lied on the forms. They have said they're planning to use as evidence his published memoir, and they may also introduce contents from a laptop that he left at a Delaware repair shop and never retrieved. The contents made their way to Republicans in 2020 and were publicly leaked, revealing embarrassing and personal photos in which he's often nude and doing drugs and messages in which he asks dealers about scores.\n\nThe judge will ask a group of prospective jurors a series of questions to determine whether they can serve impartially on the jury, including whether they have donated to political campaigns or run for political office. She will ask whether their views about the 2024 presidential campaign prevent them from being impartial.\n\nShe's also going to ask whether prospective jurors believe Hunter Biden is being prosecuted because his father is the president. Also, she'll ask about firearms purchasing and addiction issues, including: \"Do you believe someone who is addicted to drugs should not be charged with a crime?\"\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent into drugs and alcohol followed the 2015 death of his brother, Beau Biden, from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nHunter Biden has pleaded not guilty in both cases, and his attorneys have suggested they may argue he didn't see himself as an addict when prosecutors say he checked \"no\" to the question on the form. They'll also attack the credibility of the gun store owner.\n\nProsecutors, meanwhile, are also planning to call as witnesses Hunter Biden's ex-wife and his brother's widow, Hallie, with whom he became romantically involved.\n\nIf he were to be convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\n___\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press Writer Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington contributed to this report. {"uri": "8159720612", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "16:50:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T16:50:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T16:49:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://english.jagran.com/world/hunter-biden-trial-jury-selection-begins-for-hearing-on-criminal-charges-against-us-president-joe-biden-son-10164791", "title": "Hunter Biden Trial: Jury Selection Begins For Hearing On Criminal Charges Against US President Joe Biden's Son", "body": "The criminal trial of Hunter Biden kicked off on Monday in federal court in Delaware as President Joe Biden's son faces gun charges in a historic case that begins four days after Donald Trump became the first former US president to be convicted.\n\nHunter Biden, 54, arrived at the courthouse for the first trial of the child of a sitting president, in which he will face three felony charges stemming from his purchase and possession of a revolver in 2018. He has pleaded not guilty. It is one of two criminal cases he faces, with federal tax charges brought separately in California.\n\nFirst Lady Jill Biden, Hunter Biden's wife Melissa Cohen Biden and his half-sister Ashley Biden were in attendance at the trial in Wilmington, before US District Judge Maryellen Noreika.\n\n\"Jill and I love our son and we are so proud of the man he is today,\" Joe Biden said in a statement, adding that a lot of families have loved ones who have overcome addiction.\n\nTrump was convicted by a jury in state court in New York on Thursday of 34 felony counts of falsifying documents to cover up hush money paid to a porn star to avoid a sex scandal shortly before the 2016 US election that put him in the White House. Trump is the Republican candidate challenging Joe Biden, a Democrat, in the November 5 US election.\n\nHunter Biden's trial gives Republicans a chance to shift attention away from Trump's legal troubles. Trump is due to be sentenced on July 11. He has pleaded not guilty in three other pending criminal cases.\n\nIn the case brought by US Special Counsel David Weiss, a Trump appointee, last September Hunter Biden was charged with lying about his use of illegal drugs when he bought a Colt Cobra .38-caliber revolver and with illegally possessing the weapon for 11 days in October 2018. Weiss, who has investigated Hunter Biden since at least 2019, also brought the tax charges.\n\nIf convicted on all charges in the Delaware case, Hunter Biden faces up to 25 years in prison, though defendants generally receive shorter sentences, according to the US Justice Department.\n\nHunter Biden spent the weekend with his father in Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, with the pair biking and attending church together on Saturday. The president, who had been expected to depart Rehoboth Beach on Monday, traveled on Sunday evening to his home in Wilmington.\n\nNoreika began screening potential jurors for their ability to commit to serving the length of the trial, which is expected to run through the end of next week.\n\n\"Do you think you can put aside your views on gun ownership,\" she asked a potential juror, who responded that she could be impartial.\n\nOther potential jurors were asked about addiction, convictions and run-ins with law enforcement.\n\nAll 12 jurors must agree he is guilty beyond a reasonable doubt to convict.\n\nThe case is expected to center on Hunter Biden's years-long crack cocaine use and addiction, which he has discussed publicly and which was a prominent part of his 2021 autobiography, \"Beautiful Things.\" He told Noreika at a hearing last year that he has been sober since the middle of 2019.\n\nProsecutors will seek to prove that Hunter Biden knew he was lying when he ticked the box for \"no\" next to a question on a federal gun purchase form asking if he was an unlawful user of a controlled substance.\n\nProsecution lawyers revealed in court filings that they may use details gleaned from Hunter Biden's phone and iCloud account, including photos of him smoking crack and messages with drug dealers. They said they may call as a witness his former wife Kathleen Buhle, who accused Hunter Biden in their 2017 divorce proceedings of squandering money on drugs, alcohol and prostitutes.\n\nHunter Biden's lawyers have indicated they may try to show he had completed a drug rehabilitation program before purchasing the gun and may have considered his answer on the gun purchase form to be truthful.\n\nA plea agreement that would have resolved the gun and tax charges without prison time collapsed last year after Noreika questioned the extent of the immunity it extended to Biden. Hunter Biden's lawyers blamed Republican pressure for the failure of the plea agreement.\n\nNoreika entered multiple orders over the weekend that were requested by prosecutors and that appeared to undercut Biden's legal strategy.\n\nThe judge said Biden's legal team could not introduce expert testimony that people suffering from substance abuse disorder might not consider themselves an addict.\n\nThat testimony could have helped Biden show that he did not know he was lying on the background check form. The government is required to prove that Biden knowingly lied.\n\nCongressional Republicans spent years in vain trying to find evidence of a corrupt link between Hunter Biden's foreign business dealings, including work for Ukrainian energy company Burisma, and his father's political power.", "source": {"uri": "english.jagran.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Jagran English"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-06-377172989", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "12:22:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T12:22:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T06:29:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.rocketcitynow.com/article/news/nation-world/jury-selection-beginning-against-president-joe-bidens-son-hunter/507-98dddcc6-b87f-41d0-8d0b-b05ad9292666", "title": "Jury selection is beginning in a federal gun case against President Joe Biden's son Hunter", "body": "WILMINGTON, Del. -- Jury selection is to begin Monday in a federal gun case against President Joe Biden's son Hunter after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election.\n\nHunter Biden, who spent the weekend with his father, has been charged in Delaware with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application used to screen firearms applicants when he said he was not a drug user, and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department, after Republicans decried the now-defunct deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial comes just days after Donald Trump, Republicans' presumptive 2024 presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. A jury found the former president guilty of a scheme to cover up a hush money payment to a porn actor to fend off damage to his 2016 presidential campaign. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the criminal courtroom has taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nHunter Biden is also facing a separate trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through a deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed. The lawyers squabbled over the agreement, could not come to a resolution, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nThis trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs -- which Republicans have seized on without evidence to try to paint the Biden family as corrupt. But it will excavate some of Hunter Biden's darkest moments and put them on display.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about the well-being and sobriety of his only living son and who must now watch as those painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. He's also protective: Hunter Biden was with his father all weekend before the case began, biking with his dad and attending church together.\n\nPresident Biden, in a last-minute switch in plans, shifted from his Rehoboth Beach home back to his Wilmington compound on Sunday evening. Boarding a helicopter on Sunday was the only time the president was seen publicly without his son all weekend.\n\nAllies are also worried the trial could become a distraction as the president tries to campaign under anemic poll numbers and as he is preparing for an upcoming presidential debate while the proceedings play out.\n\nProsecutors are hoping to show Hunter Biden was in the throes of addiction when he bought the gun and therefore lied on the forms. They have said they're planning to use as evidence his published memoir, and they may also introduce contents from a laptop that he left at a Delaware repair shop and never retrieved. The contents made their way to Republicans in 2020 and were publicly leaked, revealing embarrassing and personal photos in which he's often nude and doing drugs and messages in which he asks dealers about scores.\n\nThe judge will ask a group of prospective jurors a series of questions to determine whether they can serve impartially on the jury, including whether they have donated to political campaigns or run for political office. She will ask whether their views about the 2024 presidential campaign prevent them from being impartial.\n\nShe's also going to ask whether prospective jurors believe Hunter Biden is being prosecuted because his father is the president. Also, she'll ask about firearms purchasing and addiction issues, including: \"Do you believe someone who is addicted to drugs should not be charged with a crime?\"\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent into drugs and alcohol followed the 2015 death of his brother, Beau Biden, from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nHunter Biden has pleaded not guilty in both cases, and his attorneys have suggested they may argue he didn't see himself as an addict when prosecutors say he checked \"no\" to the question on the form. They'll also attack the credibility of the gun store owner.\n\nProsecutors, meanwhile, are also planning to call as witnesses Hunter Biden's ex-wife and his brother's widow, Hallie, with whom he became romantically involved.\n\nIf he were to be convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.", "source": {"uri": "rocketcitynow.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "rocketcitynow.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8159480422", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "14:08:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T14:08:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T14:06:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2959848-historic-trial-begins-hunter-biden-faces-gun-charges-in-federal-court", "title": "Historic Trial Begins: Hunter Biden Faces Gun Charges in Federal Court | Politics", "body": "The criminal trial of Hunter Biden commenced in federal court in Delaware, where Joe Biden's son faces charges stemming from his 2018 firearm purchase. This case, involving claims of lying about drug use, is significant as it's the first trial of a sitting president's child. Hunter, who pleaded not guilty, faces up to 25 years if convicted.\n\nThe criminal trial of Hunter Biden kicked off on Monday in federal court in Delaware as President Joe Biden's son faces gun charges in a historic case that begins four days after Donald Trump became the first former U.S. president to be convicted.\n\nHunter Biden, 54, arrived at the courthouse for the first trial of the child of a sitting president, in which he will face three felony charges stemming from his purchase and possession of a revolver in 2018. He has pleaded not guilty. It is one of two criminal cases he faces, with federal tax charges brought separately in California. First Lady Jill Biden, Hunter Biden's wife Melissa Cohen Biden and his half-sister Ashley Biden were in attendance at the trial in Wilmington, before U.S. District Judge Maryellen Noreika.\n\n\"Jill and I love our son and we are so proud of the man he is today,\" Joe Biden said in a statement, adding that a lot of families have loved ones who have overcome addiction. Trump was convicted by a jury in state court in New York on Thursday of 34 felony counts of falsifying documents to cover up hush money paid to a porn star to avoid a sex scandal shortly before the 2016 U.S. election that put him in the White House. Trump is the Republican candidate challenging Joe Biden, a Democrat, in the Nov. 5 U.S. election.\n\nHunter Biden's trial gives Republicans a chance to shift attention away from Trump's legal troubles. Trump is due to be sentenced on July 11. He has pleaded not guilty in three other pending criminal cases. In the case brought by U.S. Special Counsel David Weiss, a Trump appointee, last September Hunter Biden was charged with lying about his use of illegal drugs when he bought a Colt Cobra .38-caliber revolver and with illegally possessing the weapon for 11 days in October 2018. Weiss, who has investigated Hunter Biden since at least 2019, also brought the tax charges.\n\nIf convicted on all charges in the Delaware case, Hunter Biden faces up to 25 years in prison, though defendants generally receive shorter sentences, according to the U.S. Justice Department. Hunter Biden spent the weekend with his father in Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, with the pair biking and attending church together on Saturday. The president, who had been expected to depart Rehoboth Beach on Monday, traveled on Sunday evening to his home in Wilmington.\n\nPOTENTIAL JURORS Noreika began screening potential jurors for their ability to commit to serving the length of the trial, which is expected to run through the end of next week.\n\n\"Do you think you can put aside your views on gun ownership,\" she asked a potential juror, who responded that she could be impartial. Other potential jurors were asked about addiction, convictions and run-ins with law enforcement.\n\nAll 12 jurors must agree he is guilty beyond a reasonable doubt to convict. The case is expected to center on Hunter Biden's years-long crack cocaine use and addiction, which he has discussed publicly and which was a prominent part of his 2021 autobiography, \"Beautiful Things.\" He told Noreika at a hearing last year that he has been sober since the middle of 2019.\n\nProsecutors will seek to prove that Hunter Biden knew he was lying when he ticked the box for \"no\" next to a question on a federal gun purchase form asking if he was an unlawful user of a controlled substance. Prosecution lawyers revealed in court filings that they may use details gleaned from Hunter Biden's phone and iCloud account, including photos of him smoking crack and messages with drug dealers. They said they may call as a witness his former wife Kathleen Buhle, who accused Hunter Biden in their 2017 divorce proceedings of squandering money on drugs, alcohol and prostitutes.\n\nHunter Biden's lawyers have indicated they may try to show he had completed a drug rehabilitation program before purchasing the gun and may have considered his answer on the gun purchase form to be truthful. A plea agreement that would have resolved the gun and tax charges without prison time collapsed last year after Noreika questioned the extent of the immunity it extended to Biden. Hunter Biden's lawyers blamed Republican pressure for the failure of the plea agreement.\n\nNoreika entered multiple orders over the weekend that were requested by prosecutors and that appeared to undercut Biden's legal strategy. The judge said Biden's legal team could not introduce expert testimony that people suffering from substance abuse disorder might not consider themselves an addict.\n\nThat testimony could have helped Biden show that he did not know he was lying on the background check form. The government is required to prove that Biden knowingly lied. Congressional Republicans spent years in vain trying to find evidence of a corrupt link between Hunter Biden's foreign business dealings, including work for Ukrainian energy company Burisma, and his {"uri": "2024-06-377234829", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "13:17:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T13:17:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T12:56:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/hunter-biden-and-first-lady-jill-biden-arrive-for-jury-selection-in-his-federal-gun/article_e7832332-98b4-5ef1-bb43-7cc97d258441.html", "title": "Hunter Biden and first lady Jill Biden arrive for jury selection in his federal gun case", "body": "By RANDALL CHASE, CLAUDIA LAUER, MICHAEL KUNZELMAN and COLLEEN LONG - Associated Press\n\nWILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- President Joe Biden's son Hunter arrived at court on Monday for jury selection in a federal gun case against him after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. First lady Jill Biden arrived shortly after, entering the courthouse in support of her son.\n\nHunter Biden, who spent the weekend with his parents, has been charged in Delaware with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application used to screen firearms applicants when he said he was not a drug user, and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department, after Republicans decried the now-defunct deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial comes just days after Donald Trump, Republicans' presumptive 2024 presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. A jury found the former president guilty of a scheme to cover up a hush money payment to a porn actor to fend off damage to his 2016 presidential campaign. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the criminal courtroom has taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nHunter Biden is also facing a separate trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through a deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed. The lawyers squabbled over the agreement, could not come to a resolution, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nThis trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs -- which Republicans have seized on without evidence to try to paint the Biden family as corrupt. But it will excavate some of Hunter Biden's darkest moments and put them on display.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about the well-being and sobriety of his only living son and who must now watch as those painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. He's also protective: Hunter Biden was with his father all weekend before the case began, biking with his dad and attending church together.\n\nPresident Biden, in a last-minute switch in plans, shifted from his Rehoboth Beach home back to his Wilmington compound on Sunday evening. Boarding a helicopter on Sunday was the only time the president was seen publicly without his son all weekend.\n\nHunter Biden arrived first at the Delaware courthouse on Monday. The first lady, who turned 73 on Monday, followed about 15 minutes later and walked briskly into court, flanked by U.S. Secret Service agents.\n\nAllies are also worried the trial could become a distraction as the president tries to campaign under anemic poll numbers and as he is preparing for an upcoming presidential debate while the proceedings play out.\n\nProsecutors are hoping to show Hunter Biden was in the throes of addiction when he bought the gun and therefore lied on the forms. They have said they're planning to use as evidence his published memoir, and they may also introduce contents from a laptop that he left at a Delaware repair shop and never retrieved. The contents made their way to Republicans in 2020 and were publicly leaked, revealing embarrassing and personal photos in which he's often nude and doing drugs and messages in which he asks dealers about scores.\n\nThe judge will ask a group of prospective jurors a series of questions to determine whether they can serve impartially on the jury, including whether they have donated to political campaigns or run for political office. She will ask whether their views about the 2024 presidential campaign prevent them from being impartial.\n\nShe's also going to ask whether prospective jurors believe Hunter Biden is being prosecuted because his father is the president. Also, she'll ask about firearms purchasing and addiction issues, including: \"Do you believe someone who is addicted to drugs should not be charged with a crime?\"\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent into drugs and alcohol followed the 2015 death of his brother, Beau Biden, from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nHunter Biden has pleaded not guilty in both cases, and his attorneys have suggested they may argue he didn't see himself as an addict when prosecutors say he checked \"no\" to the question on the form. They'll also attack the credibility of the gun store owner.\n\nProsecutors, meanwhile, are also planning to call as witnesses Hunter Biden's ex-wife and his brother's widow, Hallie, with whom he became romantically involved.\n\nIf he were to be convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press Writer Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington contributed to this report. He has pleaded not guilty. It is one of two criminal cases he faces, with federal tax charges brought separately in California.\n\nFirst Lady Jill Biden, Hunter Biden's wife Melissa Cohen Biden and his half-sister Ashley Biden were in attendance at the trial in Wilmington, before US District Judge Maryellen Noreika.\n\n\"Jill and I love our son and we are so proud of the man he is today,\" Joe Biden said in a statement, adding that a lot of families have loved ones who have overcome addiction.\n\nTrump was convicted by a jury in state court in New York on Thursday of 34 felony counts of falsifying documents to cover up hush money paid to a porn star to avoid a sex scandal shortly before the 2016 US election that put him in the White House. Trump is the Republican candidate challenging Joe Biden, a Democrat, in the Nov. 5 US election.\n\nHunter Biden's trial gives Republicans a chance to shift attention away from Trump's legal troubles. Trump is due to be sentenced on July 11. He has pleaded not guilty in three other pending criminal cases.\n\nIn the case brought by US Special Counsel David Weiss, a Trump appointee, last September Hunter Biden was charged with lying about his use of illegal drugs when he bought a Colt Cobra .38-caliber revolver and with illegally possessing the weapon for 11 days in October 2018. Weiss, who has investigated Hunter Biden since at least 2019, also brought the tax charges.\n\nIf convicted on all charges in the Delaware case, Hunter Biden faces up to 25 years in prison, though defendants generally receive shorter sentences, according to the US Justice Department.\n\nHunter Biden spent the weekend with his father in Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, with the pair biking and attending church together on Saturday. The president, who had been expected to depart Rehoboth Beach on Monday, travelled on Sunday evening to his home in Wilmington.\n\nNoreika began screening potential jurors for their ability to commit to serving the length of the trial, which is expected to run through the end of next week.\n\n\"Do you think you can put aside your views on gun ownership,\" she asked a potential juror, who responded that she could be impartial.\n\nOther potential jurors were asked about addiction, convictions and run-ins with law enforcement.\n\nAll 12 jurors must agree he is guilty beyond a reasonable doubt to convict.\n\nThe case is expected to center on Hunter Biden's years-long crack cocaine use and addiction, which he has discussed publicly and which was a prominent part of his 2021 autobiography, \"Beautiful Things.\" He told Noreika at a hearing last year that he has been sober since the middle of 2019.\n\nProsecutors will seek to prove that Hunter Biden knew he was lying when he ticked the box for \"no\" next to a question on a federal gun purchase form asking if he was an unlawful user of a controlled substance.\n\nProsecution lawyers revealed in court filings that they may use details gleaned from Hunter Biden's phone and iCloud account, including photos of him smoking crack and messages with drug dealers. They said they may call as a witness his former wife Kathleen Buhle, who accused Hunter Biden in their 2017 divorce proceedings of squandering money on drugs, alcohol and prostitutes.\n\nHunter Biden's lawyers have indicated they may try to show he had completed a drug rehabilitation program before purchasing the gun and may have considered his answer on the gun purchase form to be truthful.\n\nA plea agreement that would have resolved the gun and tax charges without prison time collapsed last year after Noreika questioned the extent of the immunity it extended to Biden. Hunter Biden's lawyers blamed Republican pressure for the failure of the plea agreement.\n\nNoreika entered multiple orders over the weekend that were requested by prosecutors and that appeared to undercut Biden's legal strategy.\n\nThe judge said Biden's legal team could not introduce expert testimony that people suffering from substance abuse disorder might not consider themselves an addict.\n\nThat testimony could have helped Biden show that he did not know he was lying on the background check form. The government is required to prove that Biden knowingly lied.\n\nCongressional Republicans spent years in vain trying to find evidence of a corrupt link between Hunter Biden's foreign business dealings, including work for Ukrainian energy company Burisma, and his father's political power.", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News18"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8159526999", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "14:37:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T14:37:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T14:36:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/as-jury-selection-starts-in-hunter-bidens-gun-case-president-says-he-has-boundless-love/article_a9fc59d5-b603-5a73-a16a-1820ca661a97.html", "title": "As jury selection starts in Hunter Biden's gun case, president says he has 'boundless love' for him", "body": "WILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- A federal gun case against President Joe Biden's son Hunter opened Monday with jury selection, following the collapse of a plea deal that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close the 2024 election. First lady Jill Biden was seated in the front row of the courtroom, in a show of support for her son.\n\nIn a statement, the president said that as a dad he has \"boundless love for my son, confidence in him, and respect for his strength.\"\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he said, adding that would have no further comment on the case. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHunter Biden, who spent the weekend with his parents, has been charged in Delaware with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application used to screen firearms applicants when he said he was not a drug user, and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department, after Republicans decried the now-defunct deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial comes just days after Donald Trump, Republicans' presumptive 2024 presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. A jury found the former president guilty of a scheme to cover up a hush money payment to a porn actor to fend off damage to his 2016 presidential campaign. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the criminal courtroom has taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nThe judge will ask a group of prospective jurors a series of questions to determine whether they can serve impartially on the jury, including whether they have donated to political campaigns or run for political office. She will ask whether their views about the 2024 presidential campaign prevent them from being impartial.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nShe's also going to ask whether prospective jurors believe Hunter Biden is being prosecuted because his father is the president. Also, she will ask about firearms purchasing and addiction issues, including: \"Do you believe someone who is addicted to drugs should not be charged with a crime?\"\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHunter Biden is also facing a separate trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through a deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed. The lawyers squabbled over the agreement, could not come to a resolution, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nThis trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs -- which Republicans have seized on without evidence to try to paint the Biden family as corrupt. But it will excavate some of Hunter Biden's darkest moments and put them on display.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about the well-being and sobriety of his only living son and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. He's also protective: Hunter Biden was with his father all weekend before the case began, biking with his dad and attending church together.\n\nPresident Biden, in a last-minute switch in plans, shifted from his Rehoboth Beach home back to his Wilmington compound on Sunday evening. Boarding a helicopter on Sunday was the only time the president was seen publicly without his son all weekend.\n\nHunter Biden arrived first to the Delaware courthouse on Monday. The first lady, who turned 73 on Monday, followed about 15 minutes later and walked briskly into court, flanked by U.S. Secret Service agents. Hunter Biden's sister Ashley Biden was also in court to support him. The president was at their Wilmington home until he left later in the day for a campaign reception in Greenwich, Connecticut.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAllies are also worried the trial could become a distraction as the president tries to campaign under anemic poll numbers and as he is preparing for an upcoming presidential debate while the proceedings play out.\n\nProsecutors hope to show Hunter Biden was in the throes of addiction when he bought the gun and therefore lied on the forms. They have said they're planning to use as evidence his published memoir, and they may also introduce contents from a laptop that he left at a Delaware repair shop and never retrieved. The contents made their way to Republicans in 2020 and were publicly leaked, revealing embarrassing and personal photos in which he's often nude and doing drugs and messages in which he asks dealers about scores.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent into drugs and alcohol followed the 2015 death of his brother, Beau Biden, from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nHunter Biden has pleaded not guilty in both cases, and his attorneys have suggested they may argue he didn't see himself as an addict when prosecutors say he checked \"no\" to the question on the form. They'll also attack the credibility of the gun store owner.\n\nProsecutors, meanwhile, are also planning to call as witnesses Hunter Biden's ex-wife and his brother's widow, Hallie, with whom he became romantically involved.\n\nIf he were to be convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\n___\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press Writer Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington contributed to this report.
